results.content: Perfect Course to learn to host basic projects on Heroku. It is taught by very few instructors and John did it perfectly. The best feature being you get all your queries answered within 24 hours of posting them.
results.content_html: Perfect Course to learn to host basic projects on Heroku. It is taught by very few instructors and John did it perfectly. The best feature being you get all your queries answered within 24 hours of posting them.

results.content:
The course seems incomplete according to it's title.  There is no complete workflow from local to hosting that includes any kind of dev/test/prod environment as would be expected for a hosting situation.  Instead there is more generic basic-app building as found in other courses.
How to backup the database?  Unknown.
How to maintain a separate local Dev Database and synchronize it with Prod Database?  Unknown.
What maintenance tasks would be expected in Archiving / Backing up complete dev environment vs. complete production environment?  Unknown
Can we A/B test separate environments on Heroku for testing purposes?  Unknown.

Compared to John Elder's other courses, this one seems subpar, a bit hurried and repeats much of what I've already done.
results.content_html:
The course seems incomplete according to it's title. There is no complete workflow from local to hosting that includes any kind of dev/test/prod environment as would be expected for a hosting situation. Instead there is more generic basic-app building as found in other courses.

Compared to John Elder's other courses, this one seems subpar, a bit hurried and repeats much of what I've already done.

results.content: Very good tutorial. However, the use of Git Bash on Windows makes things very difficult. I spendt lot of time trying to fix bugs with Git Bash. I have been suggested to use Windows Anaconda prompt instead of Git Bash. Maybe a tutorial with that would be better, even if it cannot handle version control.
results.content_html: Very good tutorial. However, the use of Git Bash on Windows makes things very difficult. I spendt lot of time trying to fix bugs with Git Bash. I have been suggested to use Windows Anaconda prompt instead of Git Bash. Maybe a tutorial with that would be better, even if it cannot handle version control.

results.content: Great content and delivery !
results.content_html: Great content and delivery !

results.content: I had been looking for a course that walks through deploying apps to Heroku and there isn't much out there that teaches this well. While there are moments that could have been more thorough, I was able to get through the course in its entirety deploying a Django app to Heroku. There is a lot of copy/paste happening and I found it beneficial to watch at 1/2 speed. It does its job and was worth the money!
results.content_html: I had been looking for a course that walks through deploying apps to Heroku and there isn't much out there that teaches this well. While there are moments that could have been more thorough, I was able to get through the course in its entirety deploying a Django app to Heroku. There is a lot of copy/paste happening and I found it beneficial to watch at 1/2 speed. It does its job and was worth the money!

results.content: For 5 minutes Heroku deployment the other 2 hours are worthless. I used GIT and Heroku for 6+ years on various other development platforms. Push to GIT should be one of the very first chapters not one of the very last and before any chapter dealing with pushing to Heroku. Having the same DB in development and production is WRONG! Based on my 20+ years of code development. Publish a link to the final code of the course to people can find fixes when they did an incorrect or incomplete cut and paste.
results.content_html: For 5 minutes Heroku deployment the other 2 hours are worthless. I used GIT and Heroku for 6+ years on various other development platforms. Push to GIT should be one of the very first chapters not one of the very last and before any chapter dealing with pushing to Heroku. Having the same DB in development and production is WRONG! Based on my 20+ years of code development. Publish a link to the final code of the course to people can find fixes when they did an incorrect or incomplete cut and paste.

results.content: The course help you get a Django app deployed on Heroku, but it is too improvised for my taste. The instructor seems to be recording on the fly, encountering some errors and not have prepared the course too much, so you can mimic his actions and get a running app, but he isn't explaning too much of what he is doing or giving great insights about the content.
results.content_html: The course help you get a Django app deployed on Heroku, but it is too improvised for my taste. The instructor seems to be recording on the fly, encountering some errors and not have prepared the course too much, so you can mimic his actions and get a running app, but he isn't explaning too much of what he is doing or giving great insights about the content.
